prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath the weight of woe,
When the sun still warms the air
And the gentle breezes blow?

Shall I curse the fading light
When stars prepare their evening show?
Shall I surrender to the night
When dawn waits, eager to glow?

No, I shall rise from this dark place,
Shake off the chains that bind my soul.
Embrace the world with new-found grace,
And make my broken spirit whole.

For in despair lies hidden strength,
In darkness, stars reveal their might.
The shadow's depth, the valley's length
Make sweeter still the mountain's height.

So I will waste no more in grief,
Nor let my heart in sorrow dwell.
The season of despair is brief
When hope rings like a silver bell.

Shall I wasting in despair
Let moments slip through trembling hands?
While autumn leaves dance through the air,
And time flows swift as desert sands?

The mirror shows a face grown pale,
Eyes dimmed by tears too long unshed.
What purpose serves this mournful tale
Of dreams abandoned, passions dead?

The world turns on its axis still,
Though grief may bend my shoulders low.
The sparrow sings with joyful trill,
Unburdened by my weight of woe.

Perhaps in this dark night of soul,
A seed of strength takes quiet root.
From broken parts, I might be whole;
From bitter soil springs sweeter fruit.

So let me rise from this despair,
Embrace the light that waits beyond.
For life, though fragile, still is fair
When courage breaks the dismal bond.

Shall I wasting in despair
Linger in the shadows' hold,
While golden moments, rich and rare,
Slip through fingers, growing cold?

Shall I count each bitter tear
As though they were my only wealth,
While spring still blooms from year to year,
And joy still beckons, as if by stealth?

The clock ticks on with steady beat,
Unmoved by human grief or pain.
The world spins round on tireless feet
Through sunshine hours and days of rain.

What folly, then, to spend my days
Entombed in sorrow's heavy shroud,
When life presents a thousand ways
To stand unbent, unbowed, uncowed.

So I shall rise from this dark night,
Embrace the dawn with open arms.
Transform despair to pure delight,
And find in living all its charms.

Shall I wasting in despair
Forfeit all that might yet be,
While the world beyond my care
Spins in wild infinity?

Shall I clutch at phantom pains,
Nurse old wounds that will not heal,
Count my losses, not my gains,
Blind to what is true and real?

The willow bends but does not break
When storms rage fierce across the land.
The ocean's depths remain opaque,
Yet meet the shore with gentle hand.

Perhaps in this dark night I'll find
The seeds of strength I thought were gone,
And leave these shadows far behind
To greet the promise of the dawn.

For what is life but light and shade,
A tapestry of joy and grief?
In time, the darkest colors fade,
And pain gives way to sweet relief.

Shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the void within,
While stars illuminate the air
And new beginnings wait to begin?

The hourglass spills its measured sand,
Indifferent to my silent plea.
Time moves with unrelenting hand,
Whether I weep or dance with glee.

The mirror shows a stranger's face,
Eyes hollow with remembered pain.
Yet in those depths, I glimpse a trace
Of who I was and might be again.

The phoenix rises from its ash,
Reborn through fire, transformed by flame.
What seems an end, a final crash,
Might be the start of life's new game.

So I will waste no more in grief,
Nor dwell in shadows of the past.
This journey may be hard but brief,
And lead to brighter shores at last.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to shadows of the past,
While the world beyond my care
Moves with steps both sure and fast?

Shall I count each bitter tear
As though tears were precious gold,
While the seasons of the year
Shift and change as days unfold?

No, I shall not waste away
In the prison of my grief.
I shall greet the breaking day
With a heart that seeks relief.

For in darkness stars appear
Brighter than in skies of noon,
And the path grows crystal clear
By the silver light of moon.

So I rise from depths of woe,
Shake the dust from weary feet.
Plant new seeds of hope to grow
Where despair once seemed complete.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath grief's heavy tide?
Shall I surrender to despair
With no shelter, hope, or guide?

The oak that's buffeted by storms

The night, in all its darkest forms,
Must yield when morning comes around.

Perhaps this sorrow shapes my soul
As rivers carve through mountain stone,
And what seems broken may be whole
In ways not yet conceived or known.

The candle flickers, does not die,
When brushed by wings of passing moths.
The stars still glimmer in the sky
Though clouds may dim their distant wraths.

So I shall rise from this dark place,
Embrace the pain that makes me grow,
And meet the future face to face,
With strength that only wounded know.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear his golden tongue,
Their calloused hands and faces tough
Softened as ancient words were sung.

The tavern's smoke hung thick as wool
Around these sons of Scottish soil,
Whose lives of endless, thankless toil
Had made their spirits dark and dull.

Yet Burns had walked their muddy paths,
Had known their labors, loves and wrath,
Had given voice to silent hearts
And dignity to common arts.

So when the stranger shared those lines,
Of mice and men and auld lang syne,
These weathered souls found solace there—
In verses raw and true and bare.

For in those words they recognized
Their own reflections, sanctified,
And felt, perhaps for first sweet time,
Their humble lives were worth the rhyme.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Gathered around the crackling fire,
Their weathered faces etched with life,
Found solace in the poet's choir.

The plowman's verse, so simply wrought,
Yet carrying wisdom deep as time,
Resonated through calloused hands
And hearts accustomed to the grime.

They nodded as the words took flight,
Of humble mouse and broken plans,
Of love that blooms like crimson rose,
Of brotherhood that spans all lands.

For Burns had walked their muddy paths
And known the sting of winter's breath,
Had loved as fiercely as they loved,
And feared the silent march of death.

So in that room of smoke and ale,
Where men of earth and toil convened,
The spirit of a farmer's son
Made poetry of what life meant.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Leaned forward on their wooden chairs,
Their eyes alight with memories
Of fields and toil and Scottish airs.

The bard who knew their calloused palms,
Who sang of mice and men alike,
Whose verses captured humble truths
That lightning-like their hearts did strike.

These laborers with dirt-creased brows
Found dignity in Burns's lines,
For he had walked their muddy paths
And turned their struggles into shrines.

The tavern's amber light grew warm
As quotations filled the room,
Of love and loss and brotherhood,
Of nature's grace and winter's gloom.

How strange that poetry so fine
Could spring from one who shared their plight,
A testament that beauty dwells
Where common souls reach toward the light.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Grew silent as the verses flowed,
Their hardened hands now gentle cups
To catch each word the speaker sowed.

The plowman-poet's honest voice
Echoed through centuries of toil,
Connecting souls who never met
But shared the language of the soil.

In taverns dim and farmhouse warm,
Where simple folk sought brief respite,
The democratic muse of Burns
Transformed their darkness into light.

For he had known their daily bread,
The sweat that seasons every field,
Had loved as fiercely as they loved,
And felt what hearts can never yield.

So when he spoke of Burns that night,
These men—deemed coarse by gentler folk—
Revealed a tenderness profound
As ancient kinship they awoke.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Fell silent as the words took flight,
Their weathered faces, carved by time,
Softened beneath the tavern light.

The poet of the common man,
Whose verses flowed like highland streams,
Gave voice to those who tilled the earth
And dared to harbor humble dreams.

They recognized their calloused hands
In every line he'd penned with care,
The dignity of honest work,
The weight of burdens hard to bear.

For Burns had walked among their kind,
Had known the sting of winter's breath,
The sweetness of a lover's kiss,
The shadow of approaching death.

So gathered 'round the hearth that night,
These men—deemed rough by gentler souls—
Found in those verses, clear and true,
Reflections of their hidden whole.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath the weight of air?
Shall I count each passing day
As moments simply slipped away?

No! I'll rise against the tide
Of melancholy's darkened ride.
I'll gather strength from hidden wells
Where courage silently dwells.

Despair may knock upon my door,
May rattle windows, shake the floor,
But I shall not invite it in
To make my spirit paper-thin.

Instead I'll dance with morning light,
Embrace the stars that pierce the night.
I'll find in sorrow's deepest face
A strange and unexpected grace.

For wasting hours in dark lament
Leaves nothing but a soul unbent.
So from despair's grip I'll break free
And craft the life I wish to see.

Shall I wasting in despair
Linger in the shadows there?
While the world moves swiftly on
And all my hopes are nearly gone?

Shall I count the endless tears
That mark the passage of my years?
Or measure heartbeats, one by one,
Until my numbered days are done?

The hollow echo of my grief
Provides no promise of relief.
Yet somewhere in this darkened space
A tiny ember still finds place.

Perhaps in wasting I might find
The transformation of my mind.
For in the breaking comes release—
A strange and unexpected peace.

So let me waste if waste I must
Until my sorrow turns to dust.
And from those ashes I will rise,
Reborn beneath forgiving skies.

Shall I wasting in despair
Watch as dreams dissolve to air?
Shall I let my spirit fade
In sorrows that my heart has made?

The weight of grief, a heavy crown
That bends my shoulders, pulls me down.
Yet in this darkness, I can see
A flicker of what might yet be.

For wasting serves no purpose here
Except to feed the growing fear
That joy has left and won't return—
A lesson I refuse to learn.

Instead, I'll gather broken parts,
The scattered pieces of my heart.
From fragments, I will build anew
A vessel stronger, tried and true.

Despair may claim the passing hour,
But hope remains the greater power.
So I will rise from ashes cold
To write a story yet untold.

Shall I wasting in despair
Be consumed by thorns of care?
Shall I let my spirit sink
As I stand at sorrow's brink?

Time flows on like rivers deep
While I neither wake nor sleep,
Caught between what was and is,
Dreaming of forgotten bliss.

Yet the stars still pierce the night
With their ancient, steady light.
They have witnessed greater pain
And still return to shine again.

Perhaps in wasting I have found
A truth that circles round and round:
That grief itself must have an end,
That broken hearts can slowly mend.

So I will rise from this dark place,
Lift my eyes to find new grace.
Despair may claim a moment's breath,
But never claim my soul in death.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drift like smoke upon the air?
Shall I count each bitter tear
As evidence that none draw near?

The hollow chambers of my chest
Echo with unspoken rest.
Each breath a labor, each step slow,
As through this shadow land I go.

Yet something whispers through the gloom,
A voice that fills this empty room:
"The darkness cannot claim your all
If you refuse to heed its call."

Perhaps in wasting lies a seed
Of something greater than my need.
A transformation slow and deep
Awakening from sorrow's sleep.

So I will take this broken heart
And craft from it a work of art.
For even in despair's embrace,
I find the lineaments of grace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Let the shadows claim my share
Of daylight's fleeting golden grace?
Shall I hide my weary face

Behind the veil of what might be,
Drowning in uncertainty?
Shall I count each breath as cost,
Measuring all that I have lost?

The world spins on its axis still,
Oblivious to my fractured will.
The stars maintain their ancient dance
Unmoved by my significance.

Yet in this wasting lies a seed—
A paradox of human need:
That only when we touch the deep
Do we truly wake from sleep.

So let me waste if waste I must,
Until despair dissolves to dust.
For phoenix-like, I shall arise
From ashes under newborn skies—

Not as I was, but something more:
A soul that suffering has wore
Into a vessel strange and wise,
Forged in fire, tempered by sighs.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Count the hours with heavy sighs?
Shall I let my soul repair
To the shadows where hope dies?

No, I'll rise against the tide
Of melancholy's crushing weight.
I'll cast these gloomy thoughts aside
And challenge my destined fate.

The sun still rises every morn,
Though clouds may hide its golden face.
From darkest nights, new days are born,
Each moment offers fresh embrace.

So I shall not in despair remain,
Nor dwell in sorrow's endless night.
Instead, I'll break this rusted chain
And step into revealing light.

For wasting time in dark lament
Only deepens sorrow's well.
Better to find what life has meant
Than in endless grief to dwell.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath these thoughts of mine?
Let my spirit fade to air,
As the stars refuse to shine?

Shall I count each passing day
As a prisoner marks a wall?
Watch as time slips fast away,
Heeding not my desperate call?

No—I'll gather scattered light
From the corners of my soul.
Find the courage in the night
To make my broken spirit whole.

For despair is but a guest
Who has overstayed its time.
I shall put it to the test
With determination's climb.

Sorrow may have claimed its due,
Left its footprints on my heart.
But I'll forge a path anew,
Where hope and healing both may start.

Shall I wasting in despair
Linger in the shadows cast?
Shall I breathe the bitter air
Of regrets from days now passed?

Shall I count each tearful night
As the moon observes my pain?
Or embrace the growing light
As the sun returns again?

No, I'll gather broken dreams
Scattered like the autumn leaves,
Stitch them where the moonlight gleams
Into hope my heart believes.

For despair is but a cloud
That obscures the brilliant sky.
Though its voice is harsh and loud,
It's a truth, but not a lie.

I shall rise from ashes cold,
Phoenix-like in amber glow.
Write my story brave and bold,
Plant the seeds that I may grow.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drift like leaves on autumn's breath?
Shall I yield to dark repair
In this living form of death?

Shall I count the hours gone by
As the clock ticks endlessly?
Or beneath the watching sky
Find what sets my spirit free?

I have walked through valleys deep
Where the shadows never part,
Where the silent willows weep
Echoing my broken heart.

Yet I've glimpsed beyond the veil
Of this momentary pain,
Seen how stars refuse to fail
Even through the pouring rain.

So I'll rise from this despair,
Shake its dust from weary feet.
Breath by breath, the healing air
Makes my liberation sweet.

Shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the darkened tide?
Shall I let my soul lay bare
With nowhere left to run or hide?

The weight of sorrow pulls me down
Like anchors to the ocean floor.
I fear that I might truly drown
Beneath what I cannot ignore.

But wait—a whisper through the gloom,
A memory of brighter days.
Perhaps there's yet a little room
For light to find its subtle ways.

For even in the deepest night,
The stars continue in their dance.
And morning brings its gentle light
To give all creatures second chance.

So no, I'll not waste in despair,
Though pain may be my present truth.
Instead, I'll seek the healing air
And find in grief the seeds of youth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to shadows of the past?
Shall I breathe the leaden air
Of a sky with clouds o'ercast?

Shall I count each bitter tear
As it falls upon the ground?
Shall I nurture every fear
Till my spirit's fully drowned?

No—I'll turn my face toward light
Though it filters weakly through.
I'll embrace the coming night
Knowing dawn will start anew.

For despair is but a chain
Forged in doubt's relentless fire.
I shall break each rusted link
And from ashes, rise much higher.

Time too precious slips away
When we dwell in sorrow's keep.
I choose life in full array,
Sowing joy that I may reap.

Shall I wasting in despair
Let my heart grow cold as stone?
Shall I wander, ever bare,
Through this wilderness alone?

Shall I count each passing hour
As a sentence to endure?
Shall I let my spirit cower,
Never seeking light or cure?

No, though darkness claims its space
And the path ahead seems dim,
I will meet it face to face,
Find the strength that lies within.

For despair, though thick as night,
Cannot quench the smallest flame
That with quiet, stubborn light
Burns despite the cold and rain.

I shall gather hope's bright threads,
Weave a tapestry of grace,
And walk where my journey leads
With renewed and steady pace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Drift like autumn's withered leaf?
Shall I let my soul ensnare
In the tangled web of grief?

Shall I count each moment lost
As the hourglass empties slow?
Shall I measure out the cost
Of the seeds I failed to sow?

Nay! The universe conspires
In its silent, cosmic dance,
To rekindle dying fires
And grant each spirit second chance.

From the depths of darkest night,
Stars reveal their ancient light.
So too shall my heart ignite
With a flame both fierce and bright.

Despair may knock upon my door,
I need not bid it welcome stay.
Instead I'll seek what lies before—
The dawn of yet another day.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
The Child of My Heart

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Your laughter echoes in the vacant rooms,
Your tiny footprints fading from the sands of time.
I held you once, so fragile in my arms,
A miracle of flesh and blood and bone.

The years passed swift as summer storms,
You grew beyond my grasp, beyond my reach,
A sapling stretching toward the sun.
Now you depart to distant shores,
To forge your path where I cannot follow.

My right hand aches with phantom weight,
The memory of your small palm in mine.
My joy—how bitter now that word—
For joy implies your presence, not this void.
Yet in this farewell lies a truth:

That love released is love's most perfect form.
So go, dear child, with blessings on your head.
Though distance grows between our beating hearts,
The cord that binds us stretches but won't break.
Farewell, my joy—but never truly goodbye.

Severed Connection

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Whose tender grasp once filled my palm with life,
Whose eyes reflected stars I thought eternal.

The cradle rocks empty now, a hollow boat
Upon the shore of memory's vast ocean.
I trace your name in sand that shifts and fades,
As time, that cruel thief, steals all but shadows.

What force divides the father from his son?
What current pulls you to a distant shore?
The blood that binds us cannot bridge this chasm,
Nor can my outstretched fingers span its width.

My right hand hangs, a withered branch in winter,
No longer strong enough to guide your way.
My joy—transformed to sorrow's bitter cousin—
Lies dormant in the garden of my heart.

Yet in this parting, painful though it be,
I recognize the turning of life's wheel.
So go, bright spark, ignite your own horizon.
I stand and watch your light recede from view,
And in the darkness, learn to live anew.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Paternal Farewell

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now departing hence.
The silent house shall miss your gentle footfall,
The morning light seem dimmer without your smile.

I shaped your mind as craftsmen shape fine wood,
With careful strokes and patience born of love.
Your thoughts took form beneath my guiding hand,
Yet now you stand complete, your own design.

The years between us—swift as autumn winds—
Have scattered memories like fallen leaves.
I gather them and press them to my chest,
A wealth more precious than all earthly gold.

My right hand feels the phantom of your touch,
My joy transmuted to a bittersweet ache.
For in your leaving lies your greatest gift:
The proof that I succeeded in my task.

So go, beloved child, into the waiting world.
Carry with you fragments of my soul.
And though the distance grows with every step,
Our bond transcends all boundaries of time.

Threshold

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The fruit of years now ripened and released.
I stand upon the threshold of your going,
A sentinel between two worlds of time.

Remember how I taught your hands to write,
Your feet to walk the uneven paths of life?
My right hand guided yours through early storms,
A compass pointing toward your distant shore.

Joy—such a simple word for this complex bond
That stretches now across impending space.
The cord unravels, not in breaking strands,
But lengthening to grant you needed room.

The door stands open. Morning light reveals
The road that winds beyond my field of sight.
Your shadow reaches back to touch my own,
Then separates as you step into day.

This parting marks not ending but beginning.
The circle turns; the seasons know their time.
Farewell, my child—though heart resists the word—
My joy remains in watching you take flight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
The Reluctant Farewell

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
How strange these words taste on my trembling lips.
Like bitter herbs mixed with the sweetest honey,
They linger in the hollow of my chest.

You were the quill with which I wrote my future,
The melody that filled my silent rooms,
The ember that kept winter from my bones.
Now you depart, as all beloveds must.

I watch you shrink against the vast horizon,
A ship with sails unfurled to catch new winds.
The harbor of my arms no longer holds you;
The lighthouse of my love grows faint with distance.

Time plays its cruel trick—the swift transition
From cradled babe to stranger taking leave.
The right hand that once measured your small fever
Now waves a hesitant goodbye to ghosts.

Yet in this space between our separating worlds,
A thread of gold connects your heart to mine.
So go, dear joy, explore your boundless skies.
I'll stand here still, your anchor and your witness,
Preserving home should you need to return.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
THE POET'S VOICE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear the tender words;
Their calloused hands, their spirits tough,
Transformed like winter-weary birds.

These men who knew the mine and field,
Whose backs were bent by daily toil,
Found in those verses truth revealed—
A beauty sprung from Scottish soil.

For Burns had walked their muddy paths,
Had known the sting of poverty,
Had felt the bitter winter's wraths,
Yet sang of love and liberty.

And so they stood in reverent hush,
These laborers of common birth,
As poetry, like spring's first brush,
Restored their connection to the earth.

Such is the power of honest verse
To bridge the gaps between all men;
To soothe the soul when times are worse,
And light the human heart again.

ROUGH HANDS, GENTLE HEARTS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Gathered around the tavern fire,
Their weathered faces, creased and gruff,
Lit by a poet's fierce desire.

They wore no scholar's fine attire,
Nor spoke with educated tongue,
Yet in their hearts burned bright the pyre
Of verses memorized when young.

The ploughman's words—so raw, so true—
Resounded in their labored lives;
These simple men somehow they knew
That beauty in the common thrives.

With whisky cups held high they'd quote
Of love and loss and nature's grace,
Each line that Burns so proudly wrote
Reflected in each rugged face.

So judge not harshly those who seem
Uncouth in manner, rough in speech;
For poetry may flow like stream
In souls that learning cannot reach.

ECHOES OF BURNS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Paused in their labor, heads inclined
To catch each word—though coarse and gruff
Their hands, they possessed gentle mind.

These were the sons of Scotland's soil,
With faces weathered by the years,
Who knew the meaning of hard toil
Yet held their poetry as peers.

In taverns dim and fieldstone homes,
They quoted verses rich and deep;
Their voices rough as ancient poems
That shepherds sang while tending sheep.

The ploughman-poet spoke their truth,
Of honest work and simple joys,
Of passion's fire and tender ruth—
A language pure that never cloys.

So marvel not when callused hands
Turn pages with surprising care,
For Burns unites these working bands
With words that common souls lay bare.

THE UNEXPECTED SCHOLARS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Leaned forward, eyes alight with thought;
Their manner crude, their language tough,
Yet poetry their souls had caught.

Beneath the caps and weathered skin,
Behind the grime of daily toil,
A deeper beauty lurked within—
Like wildflowers in untended soil.

They quoted stanzas word for word,
These men who barely learned to write,
Their Scottish accents thick, yet heard
The music in each line so bright.

For Burns had given voice to those
The world deemed common, poor, and plain;
In simple verse their lives arose
Transfigured, free from judgment's chain.

Remind me, when I judge too quick
By outward signs of grace or art,
That wisdom often grows most thick
In soil we deem too coarse at start.

KINDRED SPIRITS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Grew silent as the verses flowed;
Their hands though scarred by labor tough
Reached out as if to touch each ode.

The miners, farmers, working poor—
Unlikely scholars one might think—
Yet poetry unlocked a door
Where souls could meet beyond class' brink.

They understood what Burns had known:
The dignity in common things,
The beauty in a field well-sown,
The truth that from experience springs.

No formal learning shaped their taste,
No college taught them to discern,
Yet wisdom's crop grows undebased
In hearts that from life's hardships learn.

So there they stood, these rugged men,
Transfigured by a kindred voice;
Though deemed uncouth by gentlemen,
In Burns' words they could rejoice.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
HIDDEN DEPTHS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Circled around with eager ears;
Their hands like bark, their voices gruff,
Yet poetry dissolved their fears.

The tavern hushed as verses flowed
From lips unused to gentle things;
These men who bore life's heavy load
Found solace in what wisdom brings.

A miner quoted 'Auld Lang Syne'
With perfect rhythm, perfect heart;
A farmer traced each measured line
Of 'To A Mouse' with natural art.

For Burns had walked where they now tread,
Had known the sting of fortune's whip,
Yet found in common life instead
A beauty others let slip.

So judge not by the outer shell
The depth of feeling souls contain;
In roughest stone may treasures dwell
Like diamonds waiting to be claimed.

THE PLOUGHMAN'S AUDIENCE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Fell silent, caught in verse's spell;
Their manners coarse, their language bluff,
Yet poetry they knew so well.

These calloused hands that worked the land,
These backs bent low by daily strain,
Found in Burns' words a kindred band
Who understood both joy and pain.

The tavern's smoky atmosphere
Transformed to hallowed learning ground,
As lines of verse, precise and clear,
Gave voice to truths they'd always found.

The ploughman-poet's legacy
Lived on in these unlikely hearts;
In men society deemed to be
Too common for the finer arts.

Remember this when next you meet
A soul whose cover seems too plain;
The greatest depths oft lie beneath
The surfaces we might disdain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
THE UNEXPECTED DISCIPLES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Grew still as highland mists at dawn;
Beneath their plaids and manner gruff,
A gentler wisdom had been drawn.

These sons of toil with mud-caked boots
And hands that wrestled earth for bread,
Had found in Burns their very roots—
The words they felt but never said.

They stood like ancient standing stones,
These guardians of a poet's heart;
The verses etched into their bones
Like runes too sacred to depart.

A shepherd quoted 'Tam o' Shanter'
With eyes alight like Samhain fires;
A blacksmith spoke with bardic candor
Of love that common blood inspires.

So look beyond the rugged face,
The unschooled tongue, the simple dress;
For poetry finds dwelling place
In souls the world deems less than blessed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Let my spirit fade to air?
Like a candle's dying light
Slowly dimming in the night?

Shall I count each bitter tear
As it falls for none to hear?
Trace the lines of ancient pain
Etched like rivers through the plain?

Time moves forward, never still,
While I linger on this hill
Of regret and memories past,
Holding to what cannot last.

But the stars above still shine
Through the darkness of my mind.
In their silent, distant glow
Lies a truth I've yet to know.

Wasting in despair brings death
To the soul with every breath.
So I'll rise and face the day,
Let hope guide me on my way.

Shall I wasting in despair
Watch as hope dissolves to air?
Chained to shadows of the mind,
Leaving brighter days behind?

In this valley deep and cold,
Where my spirit grows so old,
Echoes of what might have been
Haunt the spaces in between.

Time, that cruel and constant friend,
Marches toward its distant end,
While I falter, while I wait,
Trapped behind grief's iron gate.

Yet beneath the crushing weight,
Of this seemingly fixed fate,
Lies a spark that will not die,
Though the darkest clouds roll by.

So I'll shed this cloak of gloom,
Break the confines of this tomb.
Wasting in despair's embrace
Is a choice I need not face.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Dwell within this shadowed lair,
While the world in vibrant hue
Spins without me, ever new?

Shall I count each moment lost
Like winter's bitter, biting frost,
Freeze the blood within my veins,
And numb myself to joy and pains?

The clock's hands trace their endless arc,
As I remain in chambers dark,
A prisoner of my own design,
Entangled in grief's thorny vine.

But look—beyond these walls I've built,
A ray of light through cracks has spilt,
Illuminating dust that danced,
In patterns I had never chanced.

Perhaps in wasting lies the seed
Of transformation, strange indeed,
For only when we touch the deep
Can we truly wake from sleep.

So let me rise from this despair,
And breathe again the living air,
For in surrender I have found
The strength to break this hallowed ground.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Because another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flowery meads in May,
If she be not so to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall my heart burn with despair
When I see the stars above?
Or should I break what's left of me
For a fleeting chance at love?
The world turns cold, then warm again,
The seasons shift like moods of men,
If joy comes not naturally,
What care I how bright life be?

Time wastes all things eventually,
Beauty, wealth, and memory.
So I'll rise from this despair,
And breathe deeply of the air.
Life's too brief for lingering pain,
Too precious for a love in vain.
I'll walk forward purposefully,
And care not what was meant to be.

Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to shadows in the air?
Drink the poison of my grief
Without hoping for relief?

Shall I count each passing day
As the light that fades away?
Measure moments by the pain
Like the drumming of the rain?

No—I'll rise from this dark place
Where sorrow leaves its hollow trace.
I'll gather fragments of my will
And piece together something still.

The sun that sets will rise once more
To touch what it has touched before.
And I, who've wandered through the night,
Will find my way back to the light.

Despair may claim its rightful hour
But cannot claim my spirit's power.
For even in the darkest space
Hope finds its small but stubborn place.

So let me waste no more in vain
But plant new seeds in fallow plain.
And watch as life, despite despair,
Grows green and vibrant everywhere.

Shall I wasting in despair
Let the darkness claim my soul?
Shall I count each silver hair
As time demands its heavy toll?

The clock ticks on with steady beat,
While I sit frozen in this chair,
Contemplating my defeat,
Trapped within this cold despair.

Yet somewhere in the distant hills,
A songbird greets the morning light.
Its melody my spirit fills
With courage to renew the fight.

For what is life but brief candle?
A flicker in eternal night.
Yet in that glow, we find the handle
To doors that lead to pure delight.

So shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the void's embrace?
Or shall I rise to do and dare,
And claim my rightful, living space?

I choose the path that leads toward dawn,
Though steep and rocky it may be.
For in despair, no battle's won,
But hope—sweet hope—can set us free.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath the weight of night?
Shall I let my soul lay bare,
Surrendering without a fight?

The shadows creep across the floor
As minutes turn to endless hours.
I've felt this emptiness before—
This void that hungrily devours.

Yet in the darkness something stirs,
A memory of brighter days,
When joy came easy, pure, and sure,
Before I lost my way in haze.

Perhaps despair is but a test,
A mirror showing what we lack,
Revealing what we've long suppressed
Before we find our way back.

So shall I wasting in despair
Believe that all is truly lost?
Or shall I breathe the morning air
And pay whatever be the cost?

I choose to rise from ashen ground,
To plant new seeds where hope can grow.
In broken places, strength is found,
This truth, at last, I've come to know.

Shall I wasting in despair
Linger in the shadows deep?
Shall I count each falling tear
As I lie awake from sleep?

Time moves forward, never back,
Rivers flowing to the sea.
Yet my heart remains off-track,
Lost in what will never be.

Mountains stand through wind and rain,
Stars burn bright then fade to black.
All that's born must die again—
Nature gives, then takes it back.

But between the grief and pain,
Between the darkness and the light,
There exists a gentle plane
Where beauty conquers endless night.

So shall I wasting in despair
Forget the wonder still to find?
Or shall I breathe the living air
And leave my sorrows far behind?

I choose to walk with head held high,
Though storms may gather overhead.
For even as the moments fly,
I'll cherish what remains instead.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Fade like autumn's dying leaves?
Shall I count each shallow prayer
As my weary spirit grieves?

Misty mornings turn to dusk,
Hopes like candles flicker low.
Dreams once vibrant turn to dust,
As the bitter winds now blow.

Yet beneath the frozen ground,
Seeds of promise wait to rise.
In the silence, profound,
Patience holds its own surprise.

For despair is but a room
With windows shuttered to the light.
I need only pierce the gloom
To glimpse the stars that crown the night.

So shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the void's embrace?
Or shall I breathe tomorrow's air
And in this world reclaim my place?

I choose to shed these heavy chains,
To step beyond the shadowed door.
For even through the fiercest rains,
The sun waits, ready to restore.

Shall I wasting in despair
Turn my face against the light?
Shall I nurture my despair
Like a garden in the night?

Hours stretch to endless days,
Moments heavy with regret.
Lost within this tangled maze,
Where the sun seems to forget.

But what purpose does it serve
To dwell in sorrow's cold domain?
What rewards might I deserve
For cataloging every pain?

The world still turns despite my grief,
Flowers bloom though I may weep.
And time, that most persistent thief,
Moves forward while my sorrows keep.

So shall I wasting in despair
Be defined by what I've lost?
Or shall I breathe the morning air
And measure well its worthy cost?

I choose to rise with breaking dawn,
To face whatever comes my way.
For in despair, no battle's won,
But hope builds bridges day by day.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to ghosts of yesteryear?
Shall I trace each silver hair
And count each fallen tear?

The hourglass, with sand so fine,
Measures moments slipping by.
While I, entangled in the vine
Of memories that never die.

Yet what of stars that pierce the veil
Of midnight's darkest hour?
What of seeds beneath the soil
Awakening with power?

Despair may claim its territory,
Stake its flag upon my heart,
But even in its inventory,
Hope reserves a counterpart.

So shall I wasting in despair
Become a statue carved in grief?
Or shall I dance with wild air
And find in motion sweet relief?

I choose to shed this heavy cloak,
To step beyond the shadow's reach.
For in despair's unwritten book,
There lies no wisdom it can teach.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, I drift on gentle tides,
Where dreams like petals float on midnight streams.
The world dissolves, and consciousness subsides,
As I am carried to the land of dreams.

In this soft darkness, memories unfold,
Like ancient scrolls revealing hidden tales.
Secrets that daylight never dared to hold,
Now dance before me, lifting shadowed veils.

The boundary blurs between what is and seems,
As whispers echo from forgotten years.
A sacred space where nothing is as it seems,
Where laughter mingles with unspoken fears.

In my first sleep, I find a truth so deep,
That waking life can never hope to keep.

In my first sleep, the world begins to fade,
Shadows stretch across the twilight mind,
Whispers of the day begin to wade
Through currents of the dreams I'm yet to find.

The breath grows steady, heartbeat slows its pace,
As consciousness releases its tight grip.
I drift between two worlds, a liminal space,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The light that danced within your eyes now dims.
A father's heart, once whole, now breaks in grief,
As time steals what was precious beyond words.

I cradled you when stars were newly born,
Watched as you grew in wisdom and in grace.
Your laughter echoed through our humble halls,
A melody that time cannot erase.

The world awaits beyond our threshold now,
With paths that I no longer walk beside.
My blessing goes with you like silent prayer,
Though distance grows between us, wide and wide.

Remember still the lessons I have taught,
The stories shared beside the evening fire.
Carry my love as talisman and shield,
As you pursue what heavens you desire.

Farewell, my child, though parting brings such pain,
Your joy shall be the balm that heals my soul.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
So swiftly passed from cradle unto grave.
Like morning dew upon the summer grass,
Too brief thy stay in this unworthy world.

I held thee once with trembling, careful hands,
A fragile gift entrusted to my care.
Thy perfect fingers wrapped around my own,
Thy eyes reflecting heaven's purest light.

What dreams I wove around thy future days!
What castles built upon the shifting sand!
Now all collapsed beneath grief's heavy weight,
As I return thee to the waiting earth.

The house stands empty of thy gentle laugh,
Thy toys abandoned in the silent room.
Yet in my heart, thy memory shall dwell,
Untarnished by the passing of the years.

Farewell, sweet child, until we meet again
Beyond the veil where sorrow cannot reach.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now beyond my reach.
The years have turned like pages in a book,
And you must write your chapter on your own.

I taught you how to walk on steady feet,
To read the stars and navigate the dark.
Yet nothing could prepare this aging soul
For how it feels to watch you now depart.

The house grows quiet in your absence now,
Your mother's eyes hold tears she will not shed.
The dog still waits beside your empty chair,
As if your ghost might still come home to bed.

Take with you all the wisdom I could give,
The stories told, the lessons hard-won learned.
Forge your own path with courage as your guide,
Remembering the hearth where love still burns.

Farewell, dear child, though distance grows between,
Our souls remain connected, ever bound.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Though parting rends the fabric of my days.
How swift the seasons passed from first sweet cry
To this departure shrouded in the haze
Of bittersweet transition, change, and growth.

I see in you the echo of my youth,
Yet brighter burns your flame, more pure your truth.
The legacy of blood and bone and breath
Transcends the mundane boundaries of death.

The nursery songs have faded from our lips,
Replaced by wisdom's deeper melodies.
I've watched you navigate life's storms and dips
With grace that brings this father to his knees
In gratitude for time, though brief it seems.

Go forth now into worlds I cannot know,
With roots sunk deep and branches stretching high.
My love shall follow where your footsteps go,
A constant star within your changing sky.
Farewell, my child—yet never truly gone.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Departed now to realms beyond my reach.
The cruel hand of fate has snatched away
What once brought sunshine to these aging eyes.

I recall thy first breath, thy infant smile,
The tiny fingers clasping at my own.
How proudly did I watch thee learn and grow,
How tenderly I called thee flesh and bone.

The promise of thy future, bright and vast,
Now shuttered in the silence of the grave.
No father should outlive his cherished child,
No heart endure such grief and still be brave.

Yet memory preserves thy gentle face,
Thy laughter echoes through these empty rooms.
In dreams I see thee still, alive and whole,
Untouched by death's cold, unforgiving gloom.

Farewell, sweet child, until we meet again
In that fair country where no shadows fall.

In my first sleep, forgotten voices call,
Ancestral whispers from a distant shore.
They speak in tongues I somehow know them all,
Though conscious mind has never heard before.

In my first sleep, I walk through memory's halls,
Where doors lead not to where they ought to go.
Past, present, future merge beyond the walls
Of time's constraints that daylight seems to know.

In my first sleep, I touch the sacred fire,
The spark of being that connects all things.
Then deeper still I fall, drifting higher,
As my first sleep to second sleep gives wings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, I cross the threshold where
The conscious mind surrenders to the deep.
A liminal space, neither here nor there,
Where reality and fantasy steep.

The universe contracts to just my breath,
Then expands beyond all measured scope.
I commune with shadows, life and death,
Weaving tapestries of fear and hope.

In my first sleep, ancient rivers flow
Through the caverns of my resting mind.
Carrying symbols only dreamers know,
Leaving waking certainties behind.

Stars speak in languages of light and shade,
Whispering secrets older than the moon.
Worlds upon worlds in my first sleep are made,
Collapsing with the morning, all too soon.

Between heartbeats, I contain multitudes,
A thousand lives lived in that gentle fall.
In my first sleep, time itself concludes,
Then restarts with each dream's siren call.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, Sweet Child

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The light that once illumined darkened days,
A perfect love no sorrow could destroy,
Now vanished into memory's distant haze.

I held you close against life's bitter wind,
Your laughter echoed through our humble halls.
The fingerprints you left, now disciplined
To fade like whispers on these barren walls.

What father's heart can bear such sudden loss?
What mortal soul withstand this crushing weight?
I stand beneath the shadow of your cross,
And wonder at the cruelty of fate.

Yet in the silence of this empty room,
I feel your spirit dance upon the air.
Like spring's first blossom pushing through the gloom,
You leave me with a hope beyond despair.

Farewell, sweet child, though gone from mortal sight,
Your essence lives within my breaking heart.
Until we meet beyond the veil of night,
No distance, death, or time shall keep apart.

The Severed Branch

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Torn from the tree where once you proudly grew.
No father should outlive his treasured boy,
Nor watch the light extinguish in his view.

I shaped your mind like gardens tend their flowers,
With careful words and love's abundant rain.
We measured life in shared and precious hours,
Now measured in the currency of pain.

The world spins on, indifferent to loss,
While I remain, a shadow of before.
A boat unmoored, without a star to cross
The darkened waters to a distant shore.

What use these hands that once cradled your form?
What purpose now for songs left unsung?
The house stands empty in the raging storm,
With echoes of the laughter that once rung.

Yet somewhere in this grief, a seedling grows,
A testament to all you might have been.
In memory's soil, your spirit overflows,
And teaches me to live and love again.

Benediction

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own craftwork, formed of love and light.
Time's thieving hands no longer can employ
Their skill to steal you from my aching sight.

The universe that held you proved too small,
Too fragile for a soul of such design.
I trace the shadow where you used to crawl,
And drink the bitter dregs of memory's wine.

What father wouldn't trade his final breath
To grant his child one moment more of sun?
I stand between the territories of death,
And life that somehow must go stumbling on.

The stars that watched your birth now watch your flight
Beyond the veil where I cannot yet go.
They whisper that in time, all will be right,
Though how to bear until that day, I do not know.

So rest, dear child, within that distant sphere,
While I keep vigil through remaining years.
Until that day when I may draw you near,
And wash away these centuries of tears.

Inheritance

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The universe contained within your eyes.
A constellation born from mortal clay,
Returned too soon to stardust and the skies.

I taught your hands to form their letters true,
Yet never thought to teach my heart to mend.
The books we left unread, the words unspoken,
The future plans that came to sudden end.

The garden where you played grows wild with grief,
The swing still moves as if pushed by your ghost.
I search for meaning like a fallen leaf
Seeks purpose when detached from what it knows most.

Yet in this hollow space you leave behind,
I find strange comfort in remembered grace.
The way you laughed at stories freshly spun,
The serious wonder etched upon your face.

So though you journey where I cannot follow,
I carry forward all you might have been.
Your spirit flows through blood and bone and marrow,
A legacy that time cannot unpin.

The Parting Glass

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, borrowed not for keeps.
The hourglass has emptied all too soon,
And left me here to watch while nature weeps.

I counted stars with you on summer nights,
And built our castles in the golden sand.
We chased the dragons of our shared delight,
Through kingdoms fashioned by your small command.

The world seems colorless without your touch,
A painting robbed of all its vibrant hues.
The silence thunders where your voice once played,
A symphony of questions with no muse.

What father's arms can hold the weight of absence?
What mortal mind can comprehend such loss?
I stand amid the ruins of our future,
And trace your name upon this bitter cross.

Yet somehow in this darkness, I recall
The light you brought to every shadowed place.
And though the years ahead stretch empty now,
I'll carry forward echoes of your grace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Child of My Heart

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My flesh and blood now rendered unto dust.
The heavens claim what earth cannot destroy,
A soul too pure for time's corroding rust.

I watched you grow like saplings in the spring,
Your laughter sweeter than the morning birds.
The memories of you still echoing
In empty rooms that once held all your words.

The world spins on with cold indifference,
As parents mourn what nature dares reclaim.
No logic soothes this wound of permanence,
No comfort comes from speaking your dear name.

What father bears such weight and still survives?
What purpose waits beyond this veil of tears?
The clock that marks the passage of our lives
Now seems to mock the brevity of years.

Yet in this grief, I find strange gratitude
For every moment granted in your light.
Though parting leaves this bitter solitude,
Your spirit guides me through the endless night.

Requiem for a Child

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, called to distant shore.
The light extinguished in my precious boy,
Whose laughter fills these hallowed halls no more.

I taught your hands to form their letters true,
Yet failed to learn how brief our time would be.
The future plans we carefully drew
Now scattered like leaves on autumn's sea.

What wisdom comes from such profound despair?
What meaning hides behind this curtain drawn?
I search the stars for answers hanging there,
But find just silence in each breaking dawn.

The toys you loved still wait in patient rows,
As if expecting your return from play.
Your books stand sentinel in perfect prose,
Their stories paused until another day.

So rest, dear child, beyond life's stormy seas,
While I keep watch through long and lonely years.
Until that day when time at last decrees
Our souls reunite beyond these mortal tears.

So though you journey where I cannot tread,

I forge ahead with memories as my bread,
Your love my compass through this endless night.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's dearest treasure, my soul's sweet employ.
Time's cruel hand has snatched you away,
Leaving me hollow in the break of day.

Your laughter, once music that filled every room,
Now echoes in memory, a ghost in the gloom.
The warmth of your hand as it rested in mine,
A touch I shall miss till the end of all time.

The lessons I taught you, the stories we shared,
The dreams that we wove and the moments we dared.
All scattered like leaves in an autumn-swept yard,
Memories precious, yet painfully hard.

Yet in your absence, your spirit lives on,
In every sunrise and each day's new dawn.
For though you have journeyed to realms beyond sight,
You remain in my heart, an unextinguished light.

Farewell, precious child, though it breaks me to part,
You'll forever remain the best of my heart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Whose tender smile did all my world employ.
Like morning dew upon the waiting rose,
Your presence blessed the path my life chose.

The cradle empty, the lullaby still,
No footsteps patter upon the windowsill.
Where once your laughter filled these hollow walls,
Now only silence through the chambers calls.

I held you close beneath the watching stars,
Your heartbeat matching mine without the scars
That time inflicts upon the loving soul—
A parent's heart that never shall be whole.

What heavens claim you in their distant sphere?
What angels sing the songs you should hear?
The universe has called you to its breast,
While I remain, by grief and love possessed.

Yet in the whisper of the gentle breeze,
I feel your spirit moving through the trees.
Though mortal bonds are severed by death's hand,
Our souls remain eternally entwined.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, time's sweetest employ.
The light that danced within your eyes so bright,
Now journeys onward to realms beyond sight.

I cradled dreams within your infant palms,
And whispered futures in my nightly psalms.
The universe contained within your smile,
A miracle that graced my life awhile.

The garden where we walked in summer's heat,
Still bears the imprint of your dancing feet.
The books we read beneath the willow tree,
Hold echoes of the child you used to be.

What cosmic force reclaims its gifted soul?
What purpose serves this wound that leaves me whole?
The stars that guided you to earthly shore,
Now beckon you to wonders evermore.

Though tears may fall like rain upon the dust,
And grief may shake the foundations of my trust,
I release you to the winds of destiny,
While keeping safe your love inside of me.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A star returned to heaven's vast domain.
The borrowed light that blessed my mortal days
Now shines beyond where grief and shadows reign.

I trace the memory of your gentle face,
The laughter bubbling like a mountain spring.
The questions asked with wide and wondering eyes,
The simple treasures that your hands would bring.

The world seems hollow in your absence now,
The colors dimmed, the music out of tune.
The future plans we crafted side by side
Lie scattered like dead leaves beneath the moon.

Yet in this sorrow, gratitude remains
For every moment granted to my care.
The privilege to guide your tender steps,
To witness wonder in your solemn stare.

Though parting cleaves my spirit into halves,
And time cannot restore what has been lost,
I'll carry forward all you taught my soul
Of love unbounded, worth the bitter cost.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own beacon in life's stormy sea.
The flesh of flesh and blood of blood now gone,
Leaving but shadows where your light should be.

I watched you grow as saplings reach for sun,
Your roots entwined with mine in sacred soil.
Your branches stretching toward tomorrow's sky,
Unburdened by the weight of mortal toil.

The books we read, the songs that filled our days,
The quiet moments treasured more than gold.
The lessons taught with patience, love, and hope,
Now memories to carefully unfold.

What cruel design takes children from this earth
Before their stories fully can unfurl?
What wisdom hides behind the veil of death
That claims the precious center of my world?

Yet even as I walk through shadowed vales,
I feel your presence in the gentle breeze.
In every bird that sings at break of dawn,
In starlight dancing through the ancient trees.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;

So journey forth, beloved of my soul,

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;

Then walk, then run, until your wings had grown.

The world awaits with all its grand design,
Its challenges, its sorrows, and its bliss.
I cannot shield you from what you must find,
Nor would I steal from you a single kiss

Of life's sweet lips upon your eager face,
The taste of triumph earned through tears and toil.
Go forth, beloved, claim your rightful place,
Your roots run deep in this familiar soil.

Though distance grows between our reaching hands,
And years may pass like rivers to the sea,
Remember that a parent understands
That letting go is love's necessity.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A fragment of my soul now set adrift
Upon the boundless ocean of the world,
Where time's swift currents make their ceaseless shift.

I knew thee first as whispered hope and prayer,
A dream that grew beneath my watchful gaze.
I held thee close through tempests dark and fair,
And counted blessings through our numbered days.

Now autumn's golden touch has claimed my brow,
While spring's sweet promise dances in thine eyes.
The torch I carried must be passed somehow,
For such is nature's way, the old sunrise.

Take with thee all I could not learn or be,
The courage that I lacked, the dreams I lost.
Sail farther than my vision dares to see,
Unburdened by the shadows I have crossed.

And when the stars grow dim above thy path,
Remember that my love outshines them all.
For though we part, as breath must leave the laugh,
Our souls remain entwined beyond recall.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep, I wander through meadows of light,
Where shadows dance and dreams take flight.
The world recedes, a distant shore,
As consciousness slips through time's door.

In my first sleep, memories blend and swirl,
Like autumn leaves in gentle wind unfurled.
Voices echo from forgotten days,
Whispering secrets through twilight haze.

In my first sleep, I am both child and sage,
Free from the constraints of earthly cage.
The universe expands within my mind,

In my first sleep, I touch eternity's face,
Suspended in that sacred, liminal space.
Neither here nor there, but somewhere between,
Where reality blurs with what might have been.

In my first sleep, I find myself anew,
Bathed in starlight, washed in morning dew.
And when I wake, the magic lingers still,
A whispered promise time cannot kill.

In my first sleep, dreams cascade like rain,
Tumbling through the chambers of my mind,
Unbound by logic, freed from pain,
Leaving waking thoughts far behind.

In my first sleep, I drift on silver streams,

In my first sleep, voices from the past

Moments fleeting, moments vast,
Where time flows neither right nor wrong.

In my first sleep, I am ageless, nameless too,
A spirit wandering through veiled realms,
Touching mysteries both strange and true,

In my first sleep, before the world intrudes,
I taste the nectar of infinity's bloom,
And carry back these sacred interludes,

In my first sleep, the world dissolves away,
Like morning fog that yields to breaking day.
A threshold crossed between two realms of thought,
Where waking certainties are set to naught.

In my first sleep, I feel the ancient pull
Of stories whispered when the moon is full.
My body anchored to the waiting earth,
My spirit soaring to a different birth.

In my first sleep, time bends and rearranges,
As consciousness through hidden doorways ranges.
I walk with ghosts of who I used to be,
And glimpse the shadows of what's yet to be.

In my first sleep, the universe expands,

The veil between what's real and what is not
Grows thin as gossamer, then ties in knot.

In my first sleep, before dawn breaks the spell,
I gather wisdom words can never tell.
Then rise to meet the day with half-closed eyes,
Still cradling dreams beneath awakening skies.

In my first sleep, I drift beyond the shore
Of conscious thought and reasoned mind,
Where logic's chains can bind no more
And freedom of a different kind
Beckons me through twilight's door.

In my first sleep, memories unfold
Like origami birds in gentle flight,
Stories neither new nor old
Illuminated by a different light,
More precious than the finest gold.

In my first sleep, voices long since stilled
Whisper secrets in forgotten tongue,
Ancient promises unfulfilled
Mingle with songs as yet unsung,
As empty spaces become filled.

In my first sleep, I am both here and there,
Neither bound by time nor constrained by space,
Free from worry, doubt and care,
Held in the universe's embrace,
Breathing in the starlit air.

In my first sleep, before the world returns
With all its noise and harsh demand,
A sacred knowledge in me burns—
A truth I almost understand,
For which my waking spirit yearns.

In my first sleep, the veil between worlds thins,
As consciousness retreats like ebbing tide.
A journey inward silently begins,
Where mysteries of mind and soul reside.

In my first sleep, time loses rigid form,
Flowing like water through cupped hands.
Memories and visions gently swarm,
Painting landscapes of uncharted lands.

In my first sleep, I hear ancestral voices,
Whispering wisdom from forgotten years.
They speak of paths and untaken choices,
Of laughter, heartache, triumph, tears.

In my first sleep, I am both young and old,
A child exploring, a sage reflecting.
Stories of my life, both shy and bold,
Weave patterns intricate, connecting.

In my first sleep, before dawn breaks the spell,
Before the world reclaims its noisy right,
I touch the infinite, if truth to tell,
And carry starlight into morning light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
STEEL ARROW

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing night's velvet cloak with mechanical precision.
Windows aglow, a segmented comet of light,
Carrying dreamers and wanderers through the void.

Metal serpent on iron veins, rhythmic and relentless,
Your heartbeat is pistons, your breath is steam.
You cut through mountains, slice across plains,
A man-made meteor streaking between distant points.

Inside your belly, strangers sit in silent communion,
Rocked by your motion, lulled by your steady song.
Some sleep, some stare at reflections in blackened glass,
Seeing both themselves and the nothing beyond.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Shooting toward dawn with determined grace.
A momentary bridge between here and there,
Transient and eternal in the same steel breath.

MIDNIGHT TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Cleavingthe night with its mechanical might.
Iron wheels spinning tales of distance and departure,
Headlights carving tunnels through ebony space.

Passengers sway in rhythm with the track's percussion,
Strangers bound together in this vessel of transit.
Each car a world unto itself, yet connected,
Like thoughts strung together in a dreamer's mind.

Outside, landscapes blur into watercolor smudges,
Trees and hills and sleeping towns all flee backward.
Time stretches, contracts in this liminal journey,
Neither here nor there, but somewhere in between.

The train whistle cries—a primal, lonesome sound
That echoes across valleys and into memory's halls.
We are all travelers on trajectories unknown,
Arrows shot from life's bow, seeking distant targets.

We are all passengers on this arrow of time,

IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,

The steady rhythm of progress, of humanity's reach.

We are all travelers shot from existence's bow,

Our paths like railways—straight, curved, yet the same
In leading us forward through the ceaseless now.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
ABANDONED TEARS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like fair-weather friends,
Slipping down cheeks, falling to the floor,
Leaving no trace of the sorrow they were born from.

Even my grief refuses to remain,
Evaporating into the indifferent air.
I reach for evidence of my pain,
But find only dry skin where rivers once flowed.

How lonely to be forsaken by your own sorrow,
When the physical proof of heartache
Refuses to linger as witness to your breaking.

I am left with nothing but the memory
Of saltwater that once claimed my face as home,
Before deciding even that was too much commitment.

Perhaps there is freedom in this betrayal—
When tears won't stay, perhaps I too
Can learn to let this suffering pass
Into the ether, becoming nothing
But a whisper of what once consumed me.

EPHEMERAL GRIEF

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down my face in hasty departure,
Ashamed perhaps of their own existence,
Or simply following gravity's cold command.

What loyalty can I expect from liquid sorrow
When even my own heart betrays me daily?
These droplets—born of my pain—
Become deserters the moment they form.

I wonder where they journey after leaving,
These fragments of my broken spirit.
Do they join the ocean, find community there
In ways I cannot seem to manage here?

How strange to create something so intimate
Only to watch it flee without hesitation.
Perhaps we are not meant to hold our grief,
But rather to release it, let it travel

Beyond the boundaries of our fragile bodies.
Still, I wish just once these tears would linger,
Bear witness to the depth from which they came,
Instead of racing toward oblivion.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
FLEETING COMPANIONS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They betray me with their hasty departure,

How peculiar that these liquid messengers,
Born from the depths of my own anguish,
Refuse to remain as evidence
Of the storms that rage within.

Perhaps they know something I don't—
That lingering only deepens the wounds,
That freedom comes in letting go
Of what was never meant to stay.

Or maybe they are simply mirrors
Reflecting my own inability to hold on,
To grasp the fleeting moments of connection
Before they slip between trembling fingers.

So I watch them fall, these disloyal companions,
And wonder if someday I too might learn
To release myself from the grip of sorrow
As easily as they abandon me.

TRANSIENT SORROW

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They desert me in my darkest hour,
Trickle down and vanish without trace,
As if embarrassed by their very existence.

Each droplet—a tiny universe of pain—
Refuses to remain as testament
To the earthquakes shuddering through my chest.
They escape, leaving no evidence behind.

Is this the nature of all suffering?
To manifest briefly before dissolving,
Leaving us questioning if it was ever real?

I press my fingers to my cheeks,
Searching for dampness, for proof
That what I feel deserves to exist.

But the tears have already joined
The invisible cycle of loss and renewal.
Perhaps there's wisdom in their departure—
A reminder that even grief itself
Is just a visitor passing through.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
Steel Thunder

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A metal serpent with a heart of burning coal.
Its whistle pierces night's thick veil, startling
The sleeping earth as ancient stories unfold.

Iron wheels on iron tracks, rhythmic and strong,
Carrying dreams and destinies through shadowed lands.
A mechanical beast singing its metallic song,
Connecting distant lives with invisible hands.

Windows aglow like fireflies in midnight's embrace,
Passengers adrift in time between here and there.
Moments suspended in this liminal space,
As landscapes blur and memories flare.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A monument to human will and restless souls.
Forever moving forward, forever departing,
A fleeting comet bound to earthly poles.

IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing night's velvet cloak with determined might.
Steel wheels spinning tales of journeys starting,
A mechanical phoenix blazing through endless night.

Carrying whispers of farewells and promises kept,
Thundering past fields where silent shadows creep.
Through tunnels where ancient mountains have slept,
And over bridges where forgotten rivers weep.

Passengers sway to the rhythm of distance conquered,
Each soul a story, each face a different map.
Thoughts like smoke from the engine, scattered and wandered,
As time and space in metal confines unwrap.

We are all arrows shot from life's straining bow,
Momentary streaks of light against the void.
Destination-bound but savoring the flow,
Of moments between departures and arrivals, enjoyed.

MIDNIGHT PASSAGE

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Slicing through shadows with mechanical grace.
A comet of steel on iron rails charting
A determined path through time and space.

It carries within its metal heart
The dreams of travelers, young and old,
Each journey both an end and start,
Each window framing stories untold.

The rhythmic clacking marks seconds passing,
A metronome counting moments fled.
Whistle crying to the night, amassing
Echoes of promises ahead.

I press my face against cool glass,
Watching darkness swallow distant lights.
Landscapes blend as we swiftly pass,
Phantoms dancing on these fleeting sights.

We are all passengers, briefly meeting,
Arrows shot toward uncertain dawn.
Our trajectories forever fleeting,
Here, then elsewhere, then gone.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A mechanical phantom born of steam and will.
Cutting through night's veil, forever parting
The curtains of darkness with determined skill.

Iron wheels spinning tales of distant places,
Carrying souls between worlds known and new.
Windows reflecting temporary faces,
Frames of light against the midnight blue.

The countryside sleeps as we thunder onward,
A heartbeat of metal on parallel lines.
Destination pulling us ever forward,
As memory fades with the passing of signs.

I count the stars between telephone wires,
String them like beads on invisible thread.
While inside me burn unspoken desires
For what waits ahead where these tracks have led.

We are all travelers on journeys unending,
Arrows in flight through the darkness of time.
Moments connecting, diverging, blending—
Eternal motion in perpetual rhyme.

NIGHT TRANSIT

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A steel constellation against night's canvas spread.
The whistle's mournful cry, haunting and departing,
Echoes through valleys where silence has fled.

Windows illuminate the rushing landscape,
Brief rectangles of light on forgotten fields.
From inside, faces gaze at their own escape,
Reflected in glass as the darkness yields.

Clackety-clack, the wheels speak ancient rhythm,
A language of journeys, of partings and returns.
Each station a pause in life's algorithm,
A moment where fate momentarily turns.

I count the miles in heartbeats and whispers,
Measuring distance in memories made.
The train curves through mountains and rivers,
Carrying stories that bloom and fade.

We are all travelers, temporary and fleeting,
Arrows in flight through the darkness of years.
Our paths intersecting, diverging, meeting—
Bound by the rails of our hopes and our fears.

This hunt continues still, it never ends—

Each poem a trophy that my spirit tends,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A canvas of thoughts inside her head.
Moonlight dances through the blinds,
Illuminating dreams of different kinds.

Silent tears may stain her pillow,
Or perhaps she smiles at memories that billow.
The world outside continues its pace,
While she exists in this private space.

Her breath, a rhythm soft and slow,
Matches the night wind's gentle blow.
Is she dreaming of love's embrace?
Or finding in solitude a sacred grace?

The sheets, her only company now,
Wrap around her like a solemn vow.
In this moment of perfect stillness,
She finds both emptiness and fullness.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A universe contained in what's unsaid.

She lies alone upon her bed
With whispers of the past unsaid
The ceiling stares with blank repose
As shadows dance where no one knows

The ticking clock marks time's slow crawl
Memories echo against the wall
A symphony of silence plays
The melody of bygone days

Her fingers trace the empty space
Where once there was another's grace
The pillow cold on one side still
A void that time may never fill

The night extends its darkened hand
Across her world of shifting sand
She drifts between what was and is
In solitude's strange precipice

She lies alone upon her bed
A story waiting to be read.

Perhaps we are all arrows in flight,
Momentarily visible against existence's void.
Briefly illuminated in our determined journey,
Before the darkness that cannot be avoided.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A metal serpent with eyes of fire, cleaving night's veil,
Whispering steel secrets to sleeping towns in passing,
Its mechanical heart pulsing with industrial might.

Through tunnels carved from mountain flesh it plunges,
Across valleys where shadows pool like ancient waters,
Carrying dreams and dreamers alike in its iron belly,
A temporal arrow, piercing hours with methodical precision.

The passengers sway in rhythm with the clacking tracks,
Lives momentarily suspended between destinations,
While outside, the landscape blurs into watercolor smears,
Time itself condensed to streaks against windowpanes.

This midnight projectile, launched from civilization's bow,
Hurtles toward dawn with unstoppable momentum,
Carrying fragments of humanity through darkness,
A collective journey etched in parallel steel lines.

NOCTURNAL PASSAGE

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Slicing midnight's canvas with mechanical grace,
A constellation of windows, human-bright,
Threading the needle-eye of mountains and plains.

The world outside dissolves to smudged charcoal,
As we hurtle forward in our metal sanctuary,
Passengers adrift in transit's liminal space,
Neither here nor there, but somewhere in between.

The rhythmic clatter speaks an ancient language,
A lullaby of distance being devoured,
While stars above trace parallel journeys,
Celestial travelers in their own timeless flight.

Within this vessel, strangers share breath and silence,
United by momentum and temporary purpose,
Our lives briefly intersecting like tracks at a junction,
Before diverging toward separate horizons.

The arrow flies unerringly toward dawn,
Piercing night's heart with industrial precision,
Carrying us all toward inevitable morning,
When darkness yields to light, and journeys find their end.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing night's velvet cloak with determined steel,
A mechanical comet with windows for stars,
Tracing humanity's path across sleeping landscapes.

The rhythm of wheels on rails keeps time
With the heartbeats of dreamers carried within,
Each clickety-clack marking seconds passed
And miles consumed by relentless motion.

Whispers of steam and sighs of brakes
Form the breath of this iron beast,
As it threads the needle of mountain passes
And skims the surface of moonlit plains.

Inside, souls sway with gentle rocking,
Suspended between departure and arrival,
Neither here nor there but somewhere between,
Existing in transit's liminal embrace.

We are all passengers on this midnight projectile,
Hurtling through darkness toward uncertain dawn,
Carried forward by forces beyond our control,
Yet finding strange comfort in collective flight.

MIDNIGHT EXPRESS

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A mechanical phoenix with eyes of ember light,
Severing the night with its determined trajectory,
Leaving only echoes and disturbed air in its wake.

The passengers within, temporal voyagers all,
Glide between worlds of was and will-be,
Their faces illuminated by the blue glow of devices,
Or pressed against windows reflecting their own ghosts.

Outside, the landscape surrenders to speed,
Trees become brushstrokes, hills mere suggestions,
As reality itself is compressed by velocity,
And distance becomes merely a concept to conquer.

The train's heartbeat, metallic and precise,
Counts out the rhythm of modern pilgrimage,
A mechanical mantra of progress and purpose,
Driving forward through darkness toward promised light.

We are all arrows in flight, seeking our targets,
Propelled by forces both within and without,
Cutting through life's darkness with hope as our point,
Aiming for destinations we can barely imagine.

IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A mechanical meteor streaking through night's domain,
Its metal skin reflecting moonlight in fractured gleams,
As it carries its human cargo through sleeping lands.

The rhythmic percussion of wheels on steel track
Forms a lullaby for weary travelers within,
Swaying in half-sleep between worlds,
Neither fully present nor completely gone.

Through tunnels carved from ancient stone it thunders,
A momentary eclipse of even darkness itself,
Before emerging again into star-scattered night,
Undeterred in its relentless forward motion.

Time behaves differently aboard this midnight projectile,
Stretching and compressing like an accordion played by physics,
As conversations bloom between strangers who share nothing
Except this temporary shelter from the world outside.

We are all just passengers on this determined arrow,
Shooting through darkness toward some distant target,
Held together briefly by momentum and shared direction,
Before scattering again at journey's end like spent force.

Stitching together distant constellations of cities

Float suspended between memories and anticipations,

The landscape outside surrenders to abstraction,
